comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: The Boy on the right seems to be carrying a whip so I suggest that he is working with the carraige company. Also the gent up front on the right is far too well dressed to be  a driver or  assistant (compared to the gentleman on left with his foot on the brake). I feel that the man on the right may own the carraige, the boy with the whip is the drivers assistant  and this may be a staged promotion photo.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I think that is the tram terminus building. Believe it or not, the main building in this shot is a Skating Rink! It's clearly marked on the OS 8" large scale town map of 1901-1902, and from the linked article, burned down in 1903. This may give an opening date: Newspaper article from Newtownards Chronicle; opening of a skating rink- Rostrevor and its attractions 26 May 1877

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Some more photos of the hotel www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=12&amp... www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=12&amp... i124.photobucket.com/albums/p2/oldwarrenpoint/2008%20webs... i124.photobucket.com/albums/p2/oldwarrenpoint/2008%20webs... i124.photobucket.com/albums/p2/oldwarrenpoint/2008%20webs... In that second photo there is no "tram terminus" building - the age of the motor car had begun - but the tram lines are still there (all courtesy of www.oldwarrenpointforum.com )

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here's a snapshot of that map (OSNI site is a bit user hostile, and doesn't allow direct links):

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: And the final bit of evidence, from the nli's own vaults: Caption on glassplate reads: Skating Ring Mourne Hotel. Rostrevor. 1536. W. L. ...and an interior shot!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Apologies - facing south-west! All those great buildings gone and now a Citroen garage. Is this Where The Mountains of Mourne Sweep Down to the Sea?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Snap! Had just found that myself. Many theatrical and musical events held here also... Freeman's Journal, 5 April 1878:
Lord Newry is now staying at the Mourne Hotel, Rostrevor. It is said that another series of amateur theatricals will be given in the Skating Rink, and that some of the officers of the 77th Regiment will perform.
Found operatic evenings, and a Grand Ball organised by the Royal Agricultural Society of Ireland (gentlemen's tickets = 1 guinea; ladies' tickets = 12s 6d!)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: So, all happy that this building was the Mourne Hotel / Woodside Skating Rink?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: 1877 opening  narrows the date down, too: 1877 to 1883.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: It's such a pity seeing how there's little if anything left of the buildings at the location. In the late 1800s there were two rival tourist operators running tourist cars up and down the Mourne coast, mostly beginning at Warrenpoint, this been Shaw's, and Norton's tourist cars, so it could either of them.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The old tram terminus building is still there, you can see it on this streetview... maps.google.ie/?ll=54.093643,-6.190345&spn=0.006443,0... ...but with newer sheds/warehouses where the tram lines used to be. It's amazing how such an established settlement can be so completely obliterated in such a short time.

comment.author: 34305619@N06
comment._content: Great bits of detective work by all!

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] See that now!  Discrimination against women in those days.  They were allowed in for half the price of the "gentlemen"  - probably felt that they could only concentrate on half the programme;-)
Before you block me Carol I'm only saying what most of the men were thinking, I don't think like that myself:-))

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Belfast News-letter, March 30, 1897.
ROBBERY FROM THE MOURNE HOTEL, ROSTREVOR. Late on the 25th inst., or early on the following morning, a robbery was committed at the Mourne Hotel, Rostrevor. It appears that the place was left secure before the employees had retired to rest, but in the morning it was found that three gentlemen's overcoats and a silk scarf, together value for £6 15s, had been removed ffrom the cloakroom, and a marble clock and vase, weighing about 28lbs, value for £20, had been taken from the drawing-room. The news was immediately communicated to the Rostrevor police.,
I don't think there can be any doubt at all that the photo shows the gang making off with the spoils in their getaway vehicle.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Belfast News-letter March 8th 1898
It is stated that the Mourne Hotel, Rostrevor, has been sold to the Great Northern Railway Company for the sum of £14,000, and that it is the intention of the purchasers to expend a large sum of money in improving the hotel.
I wonder if they were planning to install 'movable boudoirs'?
